note:
The weblog of Steve Ivy,
			going since 1999 in
			one form or another. Still something of a CMS junkie.
name: Steve Ivy

content.html:
Atopia

Archiving our anxious fears as precious artifact
We make a Story
Stripped to bare words encoding our natures faiths and selves
These and all in grit and grim warning 
Dystopia

Bleak grey hued rough hewn the view from future's window
Staring eyes in hope forlorn
Dust and ash the gifts our benefactors leave in progress' wake
Every memory and bright treasure stripped melted for coin

Mechanized servant eaters of all growing green feeling loving things
If not fled are fed
The shining things from heart head and gut once born now consumed
Our inner voice fed back become lies so sterile and ape'd

Semi-sentient vastly parasitic the collectives cancerous intent to only grow 
Choked full on us it is us in the mill in the dirty grist
The fluttering trembling lights only ours to give are drowned in grasping dark

In mirrored certainty the self-satisfied boast ignorance toast ignorance
Read our troubled Story and see
Utopia

name: Twitter: What if failure is the plan?

content.html:
Danah Boyd: What if failure is the plan?

Network effects intersect with perception to drive a sense of a site‚Äôs social relevance and interpersonal significance.

#twitter #failure #socialmedia
content.value:
Danah Boyd: What if failure is the plan?


Network effects intersect with perception to drive a sense of a site‚Äôs social relevance and interpersonal significance.


#twitter #failure #socialmedia

content.html:
Are0h is one of the main drivers behind a ground-breaking social media presence called Play Vicious (now defunct). Over on his blog he‚Äôs telling the story of Play Vicious and the challenges he, MarciaX, and the site‚Äôs members faced.

  • Recuerda PV : Chapter 1 - The Start, Part 1
  • Recuerda PV : Chapter 2 - The Start, Part 2

I had long become accustomed to navigating primarily white and male spaces, the demographic over-represented in the tech industry, so I had a frame of reference for what to expect as I logged into my first Mastodon instance.

Looking back, I can‚Äôt say it was a terrible experience overall, but what surprised me was how concentrated the monoculture of white men of various tech skill levels present. It was aggressively white.

I‚Äôm one of the cishet white dudes that populate the spaces that Ro is talking about. I‚Äôve tried over the years to be pull in more and more voices from outside that bubble though, including some time where PV was one of my main social spaces. I didn‚Äôt say much, I just tried to follow along and get a sense of what folks were talking about and where they were coming from ‚Äì and I count myself fortunate that Ro and MarciaX were always welcoming.

Since returning to the mastodon/fediverse (with Twitter‚Äôs enflam√©) I‚Äôve been keeping my eyes out for how and where I can be a more effective advocate for making the fediverse a more safe space; still with a main goal to doing a lot of listening rather than speaking.

content.html: ~ # 22:20 ~

name: On the Fedi and Viral Content

content.html:
When people praise the lack of #viral content on Mastodon (or the #fediverse in general), it‚Äôs seems to be mostly white tech folks, happy for our clever bubbles to be left alone.

But for people who desperately need to be seen and heard, going viral on Twitter is one of the only ways for their stories to get told. #BlackLivesMatter, oppression in the middle east, genocides in Rwanda and South Asia, the #metoo movement ‚Äì these movements couldn‚Äôt be ignored because they grew fast and visibly, making it hard for them to be ignored, dismissed, or covered up.

The Fediverse as it exists right now would see these movements isolated, defederated, gated by content warnings, and probably DDOS‚Äôd by bad actors running malicious instances. (‚ÄúMal-odons‚Äù?)

I guess right now I don‚Äôt want to see posts and think pieces about how ‚Äúcontent can‚Äôt go viral‚Äù on the Fediverse (whether or not it‚Äôs true) is only a net-positive. For all its faults Twitter has been a positive force for social change and visibility in millions of people‚Äôs lives.

We must learn from it and ask how ‚Äî if we are going to make a case for the Fediverse as an alternative to Twitter ‚Äî we can be better while not throwing those of us in the most need back to the wolves.

  • This post was 93% inspired by this excellent thread by @shengokai on #twitter.
  • I got that link from @[email¬†protected], thanks!
  • This meta-thread from @shengokai is also great reading on the #twittermigration

The Fediverse as it exists right now would see these movements isolated, defederated, gated by content warnings, and probably DDOS‚Äôd by bad actors running malicious instances. (‚ÄúMal-odons‚Äù?)

I guess right now I don‚Äôt want to see posts and think pieces about how ‚Äúcontent can‚Äôt go viral‚Äù on the Fediverse (whether or not it‚Äôs true) is only a net-positive. For all its faults Twitter has been a positive force for social change and visibility in millions of people‚Äôs lives.

~ # 03:25 ~

Help I‚Äôve over-devops-ed my blog

 https://monkinetic.blog/uploads/Over-engineered.jpg

                    03:25

name: Time for bi-yearly web presence maintenance

content.html:
What with Twitter (aka birdsite, hellsite, muskosite) flailing in the clammy hands of Dr. No, and interest in the federated web re-emerging, I figured it was time to review my own web presence and see what was the situation.

Dear reader, it was Not Good.

Warning one was hitting this site from my work network and getting a BitDefender screen of doom saying the site was serving a keylogger. NOT GOOD.

Then the site - which was hosted on Linode and runs my own homegrown blog software, Goldfrog - went completely down. After some ‚Äúwhere did those ssh keys get to, where is this thing anyway‚Äù I got logged in and figured out that my server had been hacked in some way, TLS and letsencrypt removed. I haven‚Äôt had time to troll the logs for evidence as to how the server was accessed, but I downloaded them and have them set aside to look later.

We Can Rebuild It

Thus entered a week of figuring out once again how the heck Monkinetic is built and deployed, migrating the code from Github to Gitlab (which I‚Äôm more familiar with due to $dayjob), and refactoring the Ansible code that builds the server and deploys the blog/content.

Finally today I got it 85% done, which is pretty good for a full migration between hosting providers (I also moved from Linode to Digital Ocean where I already have some other services).

Masto-tootly-don

With the insanity on Twitter, I logged back into my Mastodon account on toot.cafe and enjoyed the huge stream of new folks migrating from Twitter to federated platforms (mostly to mastodon.social since that‚Äôs the first/largest instance, but folks are making their way from there to smaller instances as they get more comfortable).

Apparently Mastodon 4.0 is out (release candidate) and they‚Äôve changed the annoying-until-it-was-gone ‚ÄúToot‚Äù to ‚ÄúPublish‚Äù. I‚Äôd have preferred ‚ÄúPost‚Äù myself, but ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è.

Maybe servers should just change it to suit their audience?
content.value:

Warning one was hitting this site from my work network and getting a BitDefender screen of doom saying the site was serving a keylogger. NOT GOOD.

Then the site - which was hosted on Linode and runs my own homegrown blog software, Goldfrog - went completely down. After some ‚Äúwhere did those ssh keys get to, where is this thing anyway‚Äù I got logged in and figured out that my server had been hacked in some way, TLS and letsencrypt removed. I haven‚Äôt had time to troll the logs for evidence as to how the server was accessed, but I downloaded them and have them set aside to look later.

We Can Rebuild It

Thus entered a week of figuring out once again how the heck Monkinetic is built and deployed, migrating the code from Github to Gitlab (which I‚Äôm more familiar with due to $dayjob), and refactoring the Ansible code that builds the server and deploys the blog/content.

Finally today I got it 85% done, which is pretty good for a full migration between hosting providers (I also moved from Linode to Digital Ocean where I already have some other services).

Masto-tootly-don

With the insanity on Twitter, I logged back into my Mastodon account on toot.cafe and enjoyed the huge stream of new folks migrating from Twitter to federated platforms (mostly to mastodon.social since that‚Äôs the first/largest instance, but folks are making their way from there to smaller instances as they get more comfortable).

Apparently Mastodon 4.0 is out (release candidate) and they‚Äôve changed the annoying-until-it-was-gone ‚ÄúToot‚Äù to ‚ÄúPublish‚Äù. I‚Äôd have preferred ‚ÄúPost‚Äù myself, but ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è.

Maybe servers should just change it to suit their audience?

content.html: In 8th grade my Art teacher recommended I pursue (somewhat disdainfully I suspect) ‚Äúcommercial art‚Äù (graphic design, in the 70s) because I loved straight lines and geometric shapes. If only she‚Äôd studied Hilda af Klint, Paul Klee, and other abstract artists, I might be an artist right now instead of a computer nerd ü§£ #notlikely
